At the same time you are right that nature isn't always best described in terms of smooth and gradual continua -- quantum differences also exist. 
 
 The invention of fuzzy logic helps here, since fuzzy logic accommodates classification systems that range from 2-valued (0 or 1) to multi-valued (any value between 0 and 1). E.g. an object doesn't have to be black or white: it could be black or white alternately, it could be checkered black and white; it could be some intermediate shade(s) between black and white, etc. That doesn't mean, of course, that black and white no longer have any meaning, they do, but they aren't the only values a system need take.
 
 Examples of fuzzy categories would include night and day, where dusk and dawn have intermediate values, or rain or shine, where rain can be anything from a heavy mist, through occasional showers to a torrential downpour. There is some use in simplifying a system to a 2-valued one: if you want to know whether or not to take a flashlight or an umbrella, it doesn't matter whether the darkness or rain is heavy or not, as any amount of either will make the tool useful. Still in trying to understand the system, a 2-valued scale is not necessarily going to be helpful, and we need to be wary of applying it inappropriately.

(They don't have the votes, Barney Frank has said the trans-inclusive bill will lose by 50 votes.) In the meantime, she's going to move ahead with the GLB ENDA, which does have the votes. This way both 25 million gays and lesbians benefit, as do a hundred thousand trans community members.
 
 What remains to be seen is whether the NGLTF and its allies will join James Dobson, Tony Perkins, Lou Sheldon and Pat Robertson in trying to kill ENDA.

 This issue has come up numerous times in American history. For example, women activists sought to have the 15th amendment prohibit states from denying the right to vote on the basis of sex as well as race. They argued that equality is equality; it does not stop with one group, and women had been very active in the struggle for abolition. The Republicans in Congress did not agree, and the 15th amendment was ratified without guaranteeing the vote for women.
 
 The opposite happened with the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. In the debates over this civil rights bill, women activists from the National Woman's Party lobbied to include in the bill a ban on employment discrimination on the basis of sex. The provision banning sex discrimination was included in the bill, and it passed. That is why women are protected by federal law from discrimination in employment. 
 
 ENDA is really an extension of the Civil Rights Act of 1964; it would ban employment discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation as well as gender identity, though the latter has been stripped from the language of the bill. 
 
 I disagree with you in this particular case. Transgender people have been an active and visible part of our movement for equality. Ours has been a movement to ban discrimination in employment on the basis of both sexual orientation and gender identity. Gay people and transgender people have worked together to end discrimination against all of us. I think that any civil rights bill that passes now should ban discrimination on the basis of both sexual orientation and gender identity.

 Whether our rights as gay people will be "put on hold" by keeping the transgender language in the bill depends on what President Bush will do. If President Bush vetoes ENDA with the transgender language taken out, then it won't be the transgender-inclusive language that puts our rights "on hold;" it will be President Bush and the Republican right. 
 
 I personally do not think the transgender-inclusive language will make any difference in whether the bill becomes law. The Christian right is lobbying hard to get Republicans to oppose ENDA in any form and to get President Bush to veto the bill if it comes to his desk. From what I have read, and I could be out of date in my understanding, President Bush has not addressed whether he will veto ENDA or not if it comes to his desk. I suspect he will, and the presence of transgender language will not matter in determining a veto.
 
 I do not think we should compromise on our principles for a pragmatism that is not going to succeed anyway. If what Barney Frank insists is the pragmatic approach is not going to work, then we should not even consider pursuing it.
